entry.title: Cloud BAdI to Update Sales Order in Finalize Phase
entry.content:
Cloud BAdI to Update Sales Order in Finalize Phase

As I explained in blog Sales Document BAdI Overview, there are limited sales document fields can be modified via custom logic in BAdI due to various reasons. On the other hand, we are receiving customer requirements to update sales document standard fields via custom logic to control standard business processes. It is a journey to enhance extensibility in sales document processes to better fulfill business requirements. 

Here I am happy to announce a new Cloud BAdI will be introduced in CE2508 which allows customers to modify custom fields and certain standard fields in sales document finalize phase before save. Please find detail information in https://api.sap.com/badi/SD_SLS_FINALIZE.

Why New BAdI?

As there are already many Cloud BAdIs available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, I am often asked why a new BAdI should be introduced rather than reusing existing ones. Here are some considerations we received from customers and partners regarding our existing Cloud BAdIs:

  • In transactional BAdIs like SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD or SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEM, customer can only access partial sales document information. For example, customers cannot access schedule line data from BAdI SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD. If a customer wants to use schedule line data to update custom field at the sales document header level, this cannot be achieved by implementing custom logic in BAdI SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD. 
  • The BAdI import parameter is not stable and reliable in transactional BAdIs like SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD or SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEM, as these BAdIs are called multiple times during sales document processing. 
  • In automatic channels that do not involve user interaction, transactional BAdIs are not the best option for influencing the sales document process. Instead, the BAdIs that are processed only once during document saving are more suitable for handling such use cases. For example, the SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE BAdI is only called during the save process. 
  • The BAdI import parameter is more stable in finalize phase BAdIs like SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE, and all sales document entities are accessible via this BAdI. However, it is not possible to update any sales document data in this BAdI as it was was only defined to check the sales document before saving. 

Definition of New Cloud BAdI

To address the demands from customers and partners, a new BAdI, SD_SLS_FINALIZE, has been introduced to update the sales document data during the finalize phase before save. This new Cloud BAdI has following aspects:

  • The import parameters are more reliable because this BAdI is processed during sales document save phase
  • All sales document entities are accessible through this BAdI 
  • Custom fields on both sales document header and item can be modified via this BAdI
  • Certain standard fields can be modified via this BAdI, such as the rejection reason code at the line item level

Let's take a closer look at the details of new Cloud BAdI SD_SLS_FINALIZE. 

BAdI Parameters

Following import parameters are defined in this BAdI so that customer can access those entities:

  • sales document header
  • sales document header partners
  • sales document items
  • sales document item partners
  • sales document schedule lines

Following changing parameters are defined in this BAdI so that customer can modify sales document data:

  • custom fields on sales document header level
  • custom fields on sales document item level
  • rejection reason code on sales document item
  • control fields to indicate what field is modified 

Business Example 

I'd like to use a business example to explain how this BAdI fulfills a business requirement. 

Supplier company XYZ sells products to different customers via portal. When customers place orders in the supplier portal, the OData API is called to create sales orders. The order creation process in supplier company XYZ is fully automatic. Only in exceptional cases sales experts will manually operate the sales order through the sales order UI. 

Due to fluctuations in the prices of raw materials, company XYZ generally does not accept customer orders with long-term delivery requests. To ensure financial risk is under control, system shall automatically reject customer orders requested to be delivered later than 1 month.  

Solution via Extensibility

The sales document finalize BAdI is the best option to handle this use case, as the finalize BAdI SD_SLS_FINALIZE works across all sales document processing channels. It is ideally suited for handling the automatic order creation scenario from supplier company XYZ. 

Define Reject Reason Code

Go to SSCUI 102494 to define a new rejection reason code for long-term delivery request. 

This reject reason code will be used in the BAdI implementation when customer requested delivery date is in 30 days away. 

BAdI Implementation

Open the app "Custom Logic" and create a BAdI implementation for BAdI SD_SLS_FINALIZE.

Implement following ABAP code and then publish the BAdI implementation. 

* Set the rejection reason to sales order item when customer requested delivery date is
* 30 days away
  if salesdocument-salesdocumenttype = 'TA' and salesdocument-salesorganization = '1010'.
    "check is customer requested delivery date is more than 30 days from today
    if salesdocument-requesteddeliverydate - salesdocument-creationdate > 30.
      loop at salesdocumentitems_change assigning field-symbol(<ls_item_change>).
        <ls_item_change>-salesdocumentrjcnreason = 'Z1'.
        <ls_item_change>-control-salesdocumentrjcnreason = abap_true.
      endloop.
    endif.
  endif.

Test Sales Order via UI

Create a sales order in Fiori application and set the requested delivery date within 30 days. 

Add the item and save the order. System shows nothing is rejected.

Create a new sales order and set the requested delivery date in November. 

Add items and save the sales order. 

After the sales order is saved, both sales order items are rejected with the rejection reason code 'Z1' which was set in BAdI implementation logic.

Go to status view and system indicates all items are rejected.

Test Order Creation via OData API

Call sales order A2X OData API to create a sales order. In the OData API payload, the requested delivery date is set on September 10th which is within 30 days period. 

The sales order 23311 is created via OData call. Go to system to check if line item is rejected in this sales order. 

Then create a new sales order via OData API call, and set the requested delivery to November 10th which is out of 30 days period. 

Open the sales order 23313 and check if line item is rejected automatically. 

Test Order Simulation via OData API

Order simulation via API call is also important for customer's business scenario. Since the sales document finalize BAdI is called in all sales document processing channels, using custom logic to reject line item in order simulation is also possible. 

Call sales order A2X OData simulation API to simulate the order creation and set the requested delivery date to November 10th which is out of 30 days period.

Check the OData simulation response in the right panel, the sales document item rejection fields are updated based on BAdI logic. 

Moving Forward

The sales document finalize BAdI will be helpful in fulfilling various business use cases to influence sales document processes. Currently, this BAdI is only available for sales orders and sales orders without charge. 

In the future, based on customer requirements, this BAdI will be enhanced to support more sales document types and allow the modification of additional standard fields. Please feel free to submit your requirement through the Customer Influence Portal to help us prioritize our product roadmap.

entry.title: Issues with Crystal Reports 2025 Patch 4 (Designer Crashes, Object Resizing Bug, and Selection Limit
entry.content:
Hello,
I am experiencing several issues while editing reports in SAP Crystal Reports 2025 Patch 4.

1. Crash when copying objects between reports
For example, when I have multiple reports open (e.g., Report A, Report B, etc.), if I select multiple Lines in Report A and try to paste them into Report B, the Report Designer crashes.

Copying and pasting the Lines within the same report (Report A) works fine.

The crash only occurs when pasting into another report.

Windows Event Viewer shows the following error logs:

Faulting application name: crw64.exe, version: 14.4.0.5411, time stamp: 0x688bb6c8
Faulting module name: cslibu-3-0.dll, version: 14.4.0.5411, time stamp: 0x688b8b03
Exception code: 0xc0000005
Fault offset: 0x00000000000942ca
Faulting process id: 0x404
Faulting application start time: 0x1DC1C82AB112C66
Faulting application path: C:\Program Files (x86)\SAP BusinessObjects\SAP BusinessObjects Enterprise XI 4.0\win64_x64\crw64.exe
Faulting module path: C:\Program Files (x86)\SAP BusinessObjects\SAP BusinessObjects Enterprise XI 4.0\win64_x64\cslibu-3-0.dll
Report Id: e0635b1c-94fc-4858-82fc-b8fc4c9fabee


and sometimes:

Faulting application name: crw64.exe, version: 14.4.0.5411, time stamp: 0x688bb6c8
Faulting module name: cslibu-3-0.dll, version: 14.4.0.5411, time stamp: 0x688b8b03
Exception code: 0xc000041d
Fault offset: 0x00000000000942ca
Faulting process id: 0x1C08
Faulting application start time: 0x1DC1C8311A06DAA
Faulting application path: C:\Program Files (x86)\SAP BusinessObjects\SAP BusinessObjects Enterprise XI 4.0\win64_x64\crw64.exe
Faulting module path: C:\Program Files (x86)\SAP BusinessObjects\SAP BusinessObjects Enterprise XI 4.0\win64_x64\cslibu-3-0.dll
Report Id: 201bc216-16cf-4827-a296-e432f0132a10

2. Issue with resizing Lines and Boxes using Shift + Arrow keys
When designing reports, I often use Shift + Arrow keys to resize Lines or Boxes.
Sometimes it only works on the first key press.
After that, pressing Shift + Arrow keys again does not resize the object anymore.
To make it work again, I have to first move or resize a Text Object, then resizing Lines/Boxes with Shift + Arrow works again.

3. Limitation in multiple object selection

Currently, multiple Lines or Boxes can be selected at once using Shift + mouse drag.
However, there is no way to select multiple Text Objects or Fields simultaneously.
- While Shift + mouse click allows selecting them individually,
- Selecting many items this way is very time-consuming.

I hope these issues can be addressed in a future patch.
Thank you for your attention.


Additional note
The resizing issue has existed since Crystal Reports 9, and unfortunately, it is still not fixed in Crystal Reports 2025. I was hoping it
would be resolved in this version.

Thank you.

entry.title: Re: PM Fleet objects - Equipment additional fields for ve...
entry.content:
Hello @S0027154449 

Yes, you can manage fleet objects in Public Cloud but it is not a standalone Fleet Management module like in on-premise. Instead, it is handled via the Equipment master in Asset Management:

  1. Vehicles are represented as Equipment with Equipment Category. This allows you to maintain vehicle-related master data for example license plate, vehicle type, etc.
  2. Within the Standard Fields, the system provides additional standard fields for fleet-type equipment, such as: Vehicle Type, License Plate Number, Manufacturer/Model, Year of Manufacture and Fuel Type. These are only available when you create equipment with category Fleet.
  3. Extending Fields
    • If you need more attributes, you can add them via In-App Extensibility (Custom Fields and Logic app) and expose them in the Manage Equipment app or in forms/reports.
  4. Migration Cockpit
    • The standard migration object Equipment is available in Migration Cockpit.
    • However, fleet-specific fields are not part of the delivered migration template by default.
    • To migrate vehicle data, you either:
      • Use the Equipment migration object and fill in the fields available, then maintain fleet-specific fields manually after migration, or
      • Add required fields via extensibility and include them in migration (using enhanced migration templates).

 

See below reference for further details:

Manage Equipment (Public Cloud 2508)

Migration Object Documentation: Equipment in Migration Cockpit

 

I hope this provides the desired result. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Material Document Goods Receipt Custom Field
entry.content:
Hi @Rawel 

Thank you for your detailed question. Here is why you see the same date copied into both items. From your screenshots, the root cause is in the script logic:

  • You are looping over items (for (var i = 1; i < item.length; i++)) and then formatting dates.
  • But you are storing results into shared variables (context.custom.formattedFrozenExpiryDate, context.custom.formattedChilledExpiryDate, etc.).
  • These variables are global across all items, so when the loop ends, the last value overrides earlier values and both GR items end up with the same dates.

Here is how to proceed in solving the issue

You need to bind the formatted values per item, not to a global variable. Options:

  1. Inside the loop, write back into the item. This way, each line item keeps its own date value.
  1. If you still need context.custom variables, use an array to store per-index values instead of a single global value. Then bind the per-index values when mapping to the API.

Below are some recommendations to consider

  • Make sure you keep formatting logic per item, not in shared/global variables.
  • Use arrays or direct field assignment so that BPA passes the correct field values to each GR item.
  • After changes, test again with 2 lines: you should now see Item 1 and Item 2 keep their distinct custom expiry dates.

I hope this provides the desired result. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: No Withholding Tax Line items is appearing in FB60 &...
entry.content:
Hello Everyone.

We have identified the solution.

If you are confident that the FI Withholding Tax configuration and correct FSV assignments to GL accounts are in place, please also verify the following also:

Check whether there is an ALE is set up in your system. Specifically, review the message types FIDCC1 and FIDCC2, as these can impact the calculation of withholding tax, particularly for India.
Refer to the below links and SAP Note 672040 & 450076 for more information. 

https://community.sap.com/t5/application-development-and-automation-blog-posts/another-possible-reason-for-missing-withholding-tax-at-fb60/ba-p/13484322

Solved: Missing tax line item when posting document via FB... - SAP Community

entry.title: Re: Error creating transport request ERP public cloud
entry.content:
Dear @diana_gonzalezcr60 

Thank you for sharing the detailed context and screenshots.

From what you have described and based on the errors in your screenshots; the issue is not just with your transport setup but with the extensibility model itself:

  • In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, creating transportable ABAP packages (like you would in on-premise or private cloud) is not permitted. The platform enforces the Clean Core principle, which prevents the use of classical enhancements (ENHO, implicit/explicit enhancements, transportable custom packages, etc.).
  • That is the reason why your system only offers ZLOCAL or customer-specific sandbox superpackages (like Z001) but blocks transport creation. Transports do not exist in Public Cloud, since lifecycle management is handled by SAP.

Regarding your main question about BADI_FIBRREI_WHT:

  • In Public Cloud, only released BAdIs can be implemented, and this is done via the Custom Logic Fiori app.
  • You cannot implement unreleased BAdIs (like classic BADI_WHT) directly via Eclipse ADT in Public Cloud. Those remain available only in on-premise or private cloud editions.
  • If the functionality you need is not available in the released BAdIs catalog, you will need to check the SAP Extensibility Explorer or request an SAP Influence Note to have it added.

So, to simply answer your questions directly:

  • No, BADI_WHT is not extensible in Public Cloud through ADT/Eclipse.
  • Yes, you must rely on a released BAdI via the Custom Logic app.

Here is a summary and the recommended path you can take. First confirm in the Custom Logic app whether a released BAdI exists for your withholding tax use case. If the BAdi is available, implement your logic there instead of Eclipse. If it is not available, raise an influence request or check if SAP provides alternative APIs/events.

See links below for further details

Use Custom Logic to Overwrite Tax-Related Fields and Read the Manually-Set Billing Date During Creation of Billing Process Documents

Defining Custom Logic for External Sales and Use Tax Calculation

I hope this provides the desired insights. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SR "Create Hyperscaler LB for INBOUND traffic from an...
entry.content:
The reason why you are unable to raise request "Create Hyperscaler LB for INBOUND traffic from an EXTERNAL" is because you don't have the necessary authorization to do so.

In order to submit a service request for the "Create Hyperscaler LB for INBOUND traffic from an EXTERNAL" template, an S-user must be authorized to Create Billable Service Requests at the customer number level. Upon reviewing your S-user ID, I found that the required authorization was only assigned at the installation level. Usually, you will need to contact your administrator listed in Users & Contacts - SAP for Me to have the authorization assigned.

For more detailed information on S-user authorizations required the Private Cloud Service Request application, please refer to KBA 2669783 - S-user authorizations required for the Private Cloud Service Request application - SAP for Me 

If you encounter any further difficulties or require additional assistance, please do not hesitate to contact us.

Have a nice day!

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: SAP GUI for Windows 8.10 Beta Program – Call for participation
entry.content:
Hello LAIENPING,
in SAP GUI for Windows we cannot use rounded corners everywhere due to technical limitations of the drawing we are using. Neither can we for example use the shadows that SAP Business Client uses without causing a lot of overhead.
And then rounded corners would also waste a bit more space available to the window without really adding much value.
That is why we stay with the corners we have.
Best regards,
Frank

Variable FAILED_ACTIVITY_635e74c3-9143-4fc3-8ac8-8de70dc944f1_DetailInfo is created with value: {"message":"Invalid payload","causeMessage":"Invalid payload. [Invalid value 37589. Max allowed before decimal is 3]","code":"400","correlationId":"e6b073cc-48b7-4d6a-b4da-26f76b82d7c5"}

Cheers,
Bruno

SAP Digital Manufacturing

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Data Migration and Master Data Management Best Practices with SAP BTP
entry.content:
Absolutely right — the shift from treating customers and vendors as separate entities to managing them as business partners in S/4HANA is one of the biggest challenges during migration. It’s not just a technical change but a structural one that can impact the integrity of business processes if not handled properly.

As a SAP certified partner, PiLog also put strong emphasis on solving this challenge by leveraging our Data Quality Governance Suite (DQGS) and iContent Foundry. Both play a key role in ensuring that master data is harmonized, accurate, and ready for the transition to the business partner model, reducing complexity and risk during migration.

entry.title: Re: Can we configure the maintenance order types in S/4 public cloud
entry.content: In Public Cloud, you cannot delete or configure order types like in on premise. A possible way to stop using unwanted order types is by setting restrictions in the Maintain Business Roles app. You can also restrict by not assigning a number range to the order type, but this is not a good practice because it causes errors when users try to create an order.

entry.title: From Requirement to Configuration: Your Guide to Time Valuation in SAP SuccessFactors Time Tracking
entry.content:
Embrace the Challenge: Mastering Time Valuation in SAP SuccessFactors Time Tracking

Hey everyone! Have you heard of the blog post "How to Setup Time Evaluation in Time Tracking"? If not, you might want to check it out. It's a great resource if you already have an idea of how to solve a problem in Time Valuation. But let's be real, sometimes configuring complex requirements can be quite the challenge, even with guidance.

It's like trying to teach a computer something that seems so simple to us humans. We can think of the solution in a flash, but explaining it step by step to a machine? That's a whole different ball game! The good news is, there are approaches, tips, and tricks that can guide you through this challenging but rewarding process.

The truth is, there's no one-size-fits-all solution. However, certain approaches, tips, and tricks can definitely help you find your own way. That's exactly what this blog post is here for! So, let's dive in and make Time Valuation in SAP SuccessFactors Time Tracking a breeze. Ready to get started?

 

Crafting Configurations: My Approach to Meeting Requirements

When I'm tasked with creating a configuration to meet a specific requirement, I often approach it like I'm crafting an algorithm. Depending on the complexity, I have a variety of tools at my disposal which I need to combine correctly to find a solution to the problem at hand. Sometimes, these tools may have limitations or details I'm not fully aware of, so it’s crucial to consider these constraints. Occasionally, thinking outside the box is necessary to overcome these limitations and achieve a viable solution. This process is both challenging and rewarding, and it's always exciting to see the final configuration come together.

 

Steps That Often Helped Me in Time Valuation

Everyone tackles problems differently, but here are some steps that I've found helpful in navigating the complexity of time valuation in SAP SuccessFactors Time Tracking. Not all steps are necessary in every situation, but they offer guidance that can help you discover the best approach for yourself. Generally, I follow these steps when dealing with complex requirements:

  • Understand the Requirement and the Reason Behind It: First, it's crucial to grasp the requirement and why it's needed. This initial understanding is key to setting a solid foundation.
  • Breaking Down the Requirement into Smaller Parts: Divide the requirement into smaller, more manageable parts. This makes the task less overwhelming and easier to handle.
  • Prototype the Idea: Create a prototype of the solution. Assess each part of the requirement to get a rough idea of the solution. This ensures that no detail is overlooked. Prototyping is good for visualizing how everything will integrate. And it helps to test an approach or an idea cheaply in the beginning of the process.
  • Translate the Prototype into Configuration: Convert the prototype into an actual configuration within SAP SuccessFactors Time Tracking. This is where the idea becomes a reality. The result is an assessment if the approach could work.
  • Configure a Time Recording Profile: Set up a time recording profile in SAP SuccessFactors Time Tracking.
  • Test the Configuration: Finally, test the configuration thoroughly to ensure it meets the requirement and functions correctly.

These steps are not a one-size-fits-all solution but rather a framework to help you find what works best for your specific needs.

 

The Individual Steps in Detail

Understand the Requirement and the Reason Behind It

Understanding the requirement and the 'why' behind it is crucial. There's no solution without first understanding the problem. A simple prototype can be very helpful here, as it allows you to quickly run through different examples and discuss the results with the customer. Knowing the 'why' can enable you to propose alternative, possibly better solutions. Sometimes, a customer may want a solution exactly as it was in their previous system, but better solutions can be found if the underlying reason is clear. As Henry Ford is often quoted, “If I had asked people what they wanted, they would have said faster horses.”

Understanding the Steps: A Simple Example

Let's walk through the process with a simplified example to understand the next steps.

In Germany and many other countries and regions, there are specific requirements for overtime premiums that involve calculating individual days separately and combining daily and periodic overtime evaluation.

  • A 25% premium should be calculated for the 1st to 10th overtime hour per week.
  • A 50% premium should be calculated for the 11th weekly overtime hour and beyond, as well as for the 3rd daily overtime hour and beyond.
  • A 50% premium should be paid for all overtime worked on Saturdays.

Additionally, there are often special regulations for Sundays and holidays. To make the example more relatable, I will base the following explanation on the above-mentioned requirements.

Breaking Down the Requirement into Smaller Parts

Here’s a structured approach that has often helped me when breaking down requirements for time valuation in SAP SuccessFactors Time Tracking.

First, I ask myself, "What daily actions are necessary, and what periodic results are expected?" I start with the daily actions because the results of these actions are needed to calculate periodic results. Answering this question gives me a rough structure for my solution. In this step, I also clarify which required data I need to calculate myself. A wealth of information, such as recorded working time or scheduled working time, is already available for use in set-like Time Type Groups.

Next, I consider, "What individual steps are needed to achieve these daily results?" This step brings me closer to the solution. With more experience in the capabilities and tools available in Time Valuation, this step can quickly lead to good results. Each time I practice, I get better at thinking in terms of Time Valuation concepts or thinking outside the box.

With this approach, the sequence in which the steps need to be executed to achieve the right results often becomes clear automatically.

Finally, I ask, "How can I calculate the periodic results, such as weekly or monthly ones?" This is more or less the same like the previously described step for daily results.

What Does This Mean for Our Example?

In our scenario, different overtime premiums are to be paid for different weekdays, and both daily and weekly overtime evaluations need to be conducted based on the amount of overtime worked.

In the first step, it is crucial to consider the following daily time valuations, as these times are used for the weekly overtime consideration. Here's what needs to be done:

  • Filter out any overtime worked on a Saturday.
  • Distribute daily overtime from Monday to Friday into categories of ≤3 hours and >3 hours.
  • Calculate the remaining daily overtime that was not worked on Saturday and is not >3 hours for the weekly evaluation.
  • Weekly, divide the overtime into categories of ≤10 hours and >10 hours.

In the section on prototyping, we'll look at this in more detail.

Prototype the Idea

The Benefits of Prototyping in Time Tracking Configuration

Creating a prototype isn't always necessary for every requirement. In many cases, the configuration parts identified in the previous step can be directly translated into time valuation. I usually do this for small and straightforward requirements. However, when the requirements or the steps to solution are more complex, prototyping offers several advantages.

Prototyping allows us to avoid the overhead of direct configuration in time tracking, especially when changes are frequent, and ensures that modifications on existing time valuations don't have unintended side effects. By prototyping, we can simplify certain steps and avoid configuring processes that are already well-understood. Starting with a clean slate makes it easier to tackle complex challenges and identify the necessary steps to achieve the desired result.

One of the key benefits is the ability to quickly test different scenarios and validate with the customer if the expected outcomes are met. Often, early in the configuration process, questions arise that need to be clarified with the customer. Prototyping helps in outlining the broad steps required to reach the desired outcome.

Moreover, this exercise has helped me learn to configure faster and come up with better ideas for configuration. I've also noticed that I'm increasingly incorporating restrictions of different valuation types directly into my prototypes.

To be clear, prototyping isn't always necessary, especially for simple requirements. However, for larger and more complex requirements, it has proven to be very helpful.

Don't worry if you're not that skilled in Excel; AI can be of great assistance and support here.

Creating a Concrete Example Prototype

Let's dive into a concrete example for the prototype used to determine overtime premiums.

From the previous steps, I know that I need both daily calculations, which might depend on the day of the week, and weekly calculations. That's why I've created a sample week in a table format.

Example of a prototype

In the "Daily OT" column, the prototype is simplified. I don't calculate overtime based on planned working hours and recorded working hours because it's not relevant for this prototype. The configuration for calculating overtime might already be present in the Time Recording Profile, so I don't need to complicate the prototype with it.

First, I check if the overtime occurred on a Saturday. If so, it is routed to the "OT Saturday" column. Don't know what the formula might look like? Simply ask the AI; it can be very helpful here. This overtime is not processed further but is paid with a 50% premium. The formula in my prototype looks like this:

Checking if the overtime occurred on a Saturday

If the overtime did not occur on a Saturday, it is routed to the "OT Not Saturday" column.

Route overtime when it didn't occur on a Saturday

This is an example of how the prototype can align with the capabilities of Time Valuation. Depending on whether the condition is met, the OT is routed to column C or D. This can be translated into a "Compare and Route" Time Valuation in a Time Recording Profile.

For the daily threshold check of three hours, I only use the overtime that did not occur on a Saturday. With the following formula, I move overtime > 3 hours that did not occur on a Saturday to the "Daily OT >= 3" column. This overtime is paid with a 50% premium.

Daily threshold check

For the weekly evaluation of the remaining overtime, which did not occur on a Saturday and does not exceed the daily threshold of three hours, I move the overtime up to three hours to the "Remaining OT for weekly calc." column.

Move the overtime up to three hours to the "Remaining OT for weekly calc." column

Aggregating the remaining overtime for weekly consideration is not strictly necessary. In the prototype, I fill the "Weekly Agg" column with this value to better understand the weekly results.

The actual distribution of weekly overtime is done with these formulas: Weekly overtime up to ten hours is paid with a 25% premium.

Distribution of weekly overtime

All weekly overtime greater than ten hours is paid with a 50% premium.

Determine weekly overtime greater than ten hours

The beauty of such a prototype in Microsoft Excel is that I can quickly copy the entire configuration and transactional data to test additional cases. For the second prototype, I simply copied rows 11-21 and adjusted the values in the "Daily OT" column to test another case, ensuring that my solution approach works for different scenarios.

Possibility to quickly copy the entire configuration and transactional data to test additional cases

Another example of a slightly more complex prototype

The following prototype is designed for a configuration that ensures a special overtime calculation for part-time employees.

An example of a more complex prototype

Translate the Prototype into Configuration

Translating the valuation types in Time Valuation is based either on the outlined steps to solve a requirement or on a prototype. The prototype is usually more detailed and ideally already considers the nuances and restrictions of different valuation types.

Essentially, the translation step involves answering the question: Which types of actions are needed for the individual smaller parts, and what corresponding Time Valuations exist?

For example, if I identify that filtering Overtime on a Saturday is a necessary step in solving the problem, I recognize that I need a Time Valuation with the valuation type "Filter Input Groups" along with a "Time Records Filter." Therefore, for each step of the solution, I need to find the appropriate tool from the Time Valuation toolbox.

The following classification can help with this step, and my blog post about the various valuation types can help as well <Link>.

It’s important to note that some Valuation Types are only available with a Time Tracking subscription. For the purposes of this post, I assume full access to all Time Valuation functionalities.

The mentioned blog post and official documentation will indicate if certain functionalities are only available with a Time Tracking subscription.

By describing the different types of actions, I hope to help you identify the required valuation type.

Filtering Options for Calculations of Subsets

If you need to

Like in this example

Check / Use following valuation type

Filter all records for days which meet certain conditions

Recorded working time on working days

  • “Filter Input Groups”
  • “Time Records Filter” (Partially, Time Tracking subscription necessary)

Identify time segments from all records in a Time Type Group that overlap or don't overlap a certain fixed time segment

Recorded working time in the time from 08:00 PM to 12:00 AM

  • “Filter segments from Input Groups”

Find time segments from all records in a Time Type Group that overlap or don't overlap a calculated time segment in a time type group

Find unpaid breaks overlapping recorded working time or deduct unpaid breaks from recorded working time

  • “Deduct Group from Input Groups”

Filter based on other criteria

Employees with an FTE < 1

  • “Decision by Business Rule” (Time Tracking subscription necessary)

Determine the part that is greater than a certain threshold

Overtime > 1 hour

  • “Aggregate Input Groups and Split”

Locate Time Type Group records that meet specific conditions

All records from a Time Type Group with duration < 11 hours

  • “Filter Single Records from Input Groups” (Time Tracking subscription necessary)

Decisions: Determining Next Time Valuation Steps Based on Conditions

The principle of decisions in Time Valuation is to route a Time Type Group based on whether a specific condition is met or not. If you define a condition and a Time Type Group A (necessary for subsequent calculation steps) and route it to a Time Type Group B, all Time Valuations using B will be executed. If the condition is not met and Time Type Group A is routed to Time Type Group C, all subsequent Time Valuations using C will be executed.

If you need to

Like in this example

Check / Use following valuation type

Route a Time Type Group when a fixed threshold is exceeded or not reached

Route a Time Type Group containing on-call duties for certain time valuations when the total of them is greater than 1 hour

  • “Compare Threshold with Comparison Group to Route Input”

Route a Time Type Group when a value in a certain time type group is exceeded or not reached

Route late coming time when their total duration exceeds 1 hour

  • “Compare Threshold with Comparison Group to Route Input”

Combine conditions linked with And or Or to route a Time Type Group

Route a Time Type Group A when Time Type Group B is greater than 0 and Time Type Group C is greater than 10

  • “Compare Threshold with Comparison Group to Route Input” and the Hints and Tips section in this blog post

Route a Time Type Group when a certain job info field has a certain value

Process certain time valuation only when the FTE is lower than 1

  • “Decision by Business Rule” (Time Tracking subscription necessary)

Finding the Right Valuation Type for Your Calculation Needs

Sometimes, not all calculations are straightforward, and you might need to think outside the box for certain requirements. Here's a guide to help you find the right valuation type for your specific needs.  In such cases, it's worth checking if there are any hints in the corresponding section of this blog post. 

If you need to

Like in this example

Check / Use following valuation type

Split a value at a certain threshold to get the portion up to the threshold and the portion above the threshold

For overtime up to 1 hour per day with 25% premium and 50% premium for overtime above 1 hour

  • “Aggregate Input Groups and Split”

Add values from different time type group to another time type group

Aggregate different overtime time type groups in one time type group for displaying this on the UI

  • “Aggregate Input Groups and Split”

Add a fixed value to the value of a time type group

Add an additional fixed value, e.g. when an additional flat rate of 1 hour should be paid in addition to the value in a time type group

  • “Aggregate Input Groups and Split”
  • “Create Time Record” (Time Tracking subscription necessary)

Calculate the difference of two Time Type Groups

Calculate the delta between working time and scheduled working time for posting to a Working Time Account

  • "Difference Between Threshold and Input"

Multiply the value of a Time Type Group with a fixed value

 Convert a premium to time

                                                             

  • “Aggregate Input Groups and Split” and use a factor for the Input Time Type Group. The results need to be tested extensively, especially when it is used as an input in subsequent time valuations.

Other mathematical calculations

Divide a value or calculate the modulo of a division

  • “Calculation by Business Rule” (Time Tracking subscription necessary). With this, calculations with the total of a Time Type Group are possible, but not with single records in a Time Type Group.

Additional Actions

If you need to

Like in this example

Check / Use following valuation type

If you need a Time Type Group with a certain value out of nothing

If on-call time < 1:00 per day, then use 1:00 as a minimum value

  • “Compare Threshold with Comparison Group to Route Input” for checking decisions
  • “Create Time Record” (Time Tracking subscription necessary)
  • Alternatively, “Calculation by business rule” (Time Tracking subscription necessary)

Have a time type group that is adjacent to the start or end of another time type group

When 30 minutes before and after the scheduled working time should be paid with a certain premium

  • "Filter segments from Input Groups”
  • "Create Time Record" (Time Tracking subscription necessary) Start time of the created time type group can be calculated using the end time and an offset, and vice versa.

If you need to count days that meet certain conditions

Counting all days in a month where work was recorded from home

  • "Compare Threshold with Input Groups and Count Events"

If you need to count within a day how many records are in a Time Type group

Determining a flat rate for each on-call duty within a day

  • "Create Time Record" (Enhancement available from the 2H 2025 Release, Time Tracking subscription necessary)

Round the value of a Time Type Group

Overtime should be calculated in full quarter hours

  • “Calculation by business rule” (Time Tracking subscription necessary) Only the total duration of a Time Type Group but not individual records can be rounded.

Ensure a minimum duration for a Time Type Group under certain conditions

If an employee should get paid for at least three hours of overtime if they work more than 30 minutes of overtime

  • “Calculation by business rule” (Time Tracking subscription necessary) or
  • A combination of "Create Time Record" (Time Tracking subscription necessary) and "Compare Threshold with Input Groups and Count Events"

Applying What You've Learned to Our Example

Now let's apply what we've learned in the previous section. From the prototype or the breakdown of the requirement, we know the following steps need to be translated into the configuration of a Time Recording Profile.

Filter out any overtime worked on a Saturday

  • In the prototype, the day was checked, and if it was Saturday, the overtime was transferred to a separate column.
  • In Time Valuation, it's quite similar. Using a Time Valuation of the valuation type "Filter Input Groups" combined with a "Time Records Filter," you can check which overtime was calculated on a Saturday.
  • The Time Type Group containing the calculated overtime is used as the Input Time Type Group.
  • The records from the Input Time Type Group that meet the condition defined in the Time Records Filter are routed to the Time Type Group Below. This Time Type Group contains all Saturday overtime, which does not need further processing and can be paid out directly.
  • All others are routed to the Time Type Group Above.

Distribute daily overtime from Monday to Friday into categories of ≤3 hours and >3 hours

  • Since we are not considering Sunday separately in this simplified example, the check for the threshold of 3 hours can be performed with the result in the Time Type Group Above of the previous Time Valuation. This Time Type Group contains overtime from weekdays others than Saturday.
  • The split is done using a Time Valuation of the valuation type "Aggregate Input Groups and Split."
  • We use the Time Type Group Above of the previous Time Valuation as the Input Time Type Group and define a fixed threshold of three hours.
  • In the Time Type Group Below of the Aggregation Time Valuation, overtime up to three hours is available.
  • Overtime above three hours is in the Time Type Group Above. This Time Type Group does not need further processing and can be paid out directly.
  • Since we already filtered out overtime on a Saturday in the previous Time Valuation, we only find overtime from other weekdays in both the Time Type Group Above and Below.

Calculate the remaining daily overtime that was not worked on Saturday and is not >3 hours for the weekly evaluation

  • For this step, no additional Time Valuation is necessary. The previous Time Valuations have already resulted in a Time Type Group containing this overtime.

Weekly, divide the overtime into categories of ≤10 hours and >10 hours

  • Now, only the weekly split of overtime remains.
  • For this, we use an additional Time Valuation of the valuation type "Aggregate Input Groups and Split" with the Valuation Method "Valuate Whole Sheet or Period." The previously needed Time Valuations were processed for each individual day and either had no valuation method (because the Valuation Type only supports daily calculations) or the Valuation Method "Valuate Per Day."
  • With the new valuation method, we achieve that the Time Valuation aggregates all Input Time Type Groups for the entire week and compares them with a weekly threshold.
  • We use the Time Type Group Below of the previous Time Valuation as the Input Time Type Group and define a fixed threshold of ten hours. The Time Type Group contains overtime up to 3 hours per day for all days except Saturday.
  • In the Time Type Group Below of the Aggregation Time Valuation, overtime up to ten hours is available.
  • Overtime above ten hours is in the Time Type Group Above.
  • Both Time Type Groups do not need further processing and can be paid out.
  • It gets slightly more complex towards the end because we've introduced flexible periods in the Time Recording Profile. A flexible period can, for example, span a month, and then the Time Valuation needs to be adapted accordingly.
    • If a Time Recording Approval Period with Length Leay Week is defined in the Time Recording Profile, the configuration of the Time Valuation can be done as described above.
    • For a different Time Recording Approval Period, the following changes must be made to ensure a weekly calculation of overtime:
      • The Time Type Group Below in the last daily step must be configured as a Time Container. This ensures that the result is persisted in a daily Time Container.
      • An additional Time Type Group of the Time Category Time Container reads the values from the daily Time Container into a Time Type Group, which is used as input for the weekly aggregation.
      • Both the Time Type Group Above and Below in the weekly aggregation must be configured as weekly Time Containers.

Excurs: Hints and Tips

Sometimes the possibilities are not obvious and can be hard to find. Occasionally, you need to think outside the box. Often, it's a matter of experience: if you found a way before, you'll find it much faster the next time. Perhaps you even documented it somewhere.

In the following, I'll provide some answers to configuration questions that I frequently encounter. I'm also open to expanding these tips if I receive relevant feedback on this blog post. Surely, other members of the community have helpful tips to share as well.

What's the Deal with Time Type Group Above and Time Type Group Below?

In most valuation types, you'll encounter both Time Type Group Above and Time Type Group Below. For many valuation types, it's a valid question to ask what distinguishes these and when to use which.

It's important to understand that these different Time Type Groups are used similarly to an If/Else statement in programming. For example, in the valuation type "Compare Threshold with Comparison Group to Route Input," the Input Time Type Group is routed to the Time Type Group Above if the condition is met (equivalent to the If). If the condition is not met, the Input Time Type Group is routed to the Time Type Group Below (equivalent to the Else).

If you're missing a comparison operator like '<=' in the valuation type "Compare Threshold with Comparison Group to Route Input," you can simply use the Time Type Group Below instead of the Time Type Group Above.

Admittedly, the naming of these fields is intuitive to understand only in the Aggregate and Split Time Valuation. For all other cases, you'll need to remember or refer to my blog post "How to setup Time Evaluation in Time Tracking."

Combine Conditions Linked with And or Or to Route a Time Type Group

When using the Time Valuation "Decision by Business Rule," you can easily combine partial conditions with And or Or. However, this valuation type cannot cover all use cases. For instance, it's not possible to configure conditions with different Time Type Groups in a single business rule, such as when Time Type Group A > 0 and Time Type Group B > 10.

It's good to know that multiple Time Valuations of the type "Compare Threshold with Comparison Group to Route Input" can achieve this.

Logical And

Perhaps you recall the concept of decisions in Time Valuation from the paragraph on translation.

The principle of decisions in Time Valuation is to route a Time Type Group based on whether a specific condition is met or not. If you define a condition and a Time Type Group A (necessary for subsequent calculation steps) and route it to a Time Type Group B, all Time Valuations using B will be executed. If the condition is not met and Time Type Group A is routed to Time Type Group C, all subsequent Time Valuations using C will be executed.

Thus, you can easily configure a logica And. Two Time Valuations of the valuation type "Compare Threshold with Comparison Group to Route Input" are needed in sequence.

For example: A specific calculation with a Time Type Group containing recorded Overtime should occur if Time Type Group A > 0 AND Time Type Group B > 10.

The first Time Valuation has the Time Type Group with the recorded Overtime as Input and checks if Time Type Group A > 0. The Time Type Group with the recorded Overtime is routed to the Time Type Group TEMP, which is defined as Time Type Group Above.

The second Time Valuation has the Time Type Group TEMP as Input and checks if Time Type Group B > 10. The Time Type Group TEMP is routed to the Time Type Group Above if the condition is met. This Time Type Group is only filled if Time Type Group A > 0 and Time Type Group B > 10.

Logical Or

For a logical Or, we again consider the concept of decisions in Time Valuation as described above.

Three Time Valuations of the type "Compare Threshold with Comparison Group to Route Input" and one of the type "Aggregate Input Groups and Split" are needed in sequence.

For example: A specific calculation with a Time Type Group containing recorded Overtime should occur if Time Type Group A > 0 OR Time Type Group B > 10.

The first Time Valuation has the Time Type Group with the recorded Overtime as Input and checks if Time Type Group A > 0. The Time Type Group with the recorded Overtime is routed to the Time Type Group TEMP, which is defined as Time Type Group Above.

The second Time Valuation also has the Time Type Group with the recorded Overtime as Input and checks if Time Type Group B > 10. The Time Type Group with the recorded Overtime is routed to the Time Type Group Above (TEMP1) if the condition is met.

In an Aggregation Time Valuation, the two Time Type Groups TEMP and TEMP1 are aggregated into a Time Type Group TEMP2.

The final Time Valuation has the Time Type Group with the recorded Overtime as Input and checks if Time Type Group TEMP2 > 0. The Time Type Group with the recorded Overtime is routed to the Time Type Group Above if the condition is met. The Time Type Group Above contains the recorded Overtime if either the first or the second partial condition is met.

Using >= Instead of >

The valuation type "Compare Threshold with Comparison Group to Route Input" implicitly uses the comparison operator > and checks if the duration in the Comparison Group is greater than the Threshold.

Since the comparison operator cannot be changed, there must be another way to configure it if a comparison operator >= is needed.

The following approach can be taken if the comparison cannot be configured using a Time Valuation of the type "Decision by Business Rule."

It is relatively simple. If the threshold value is reduced by 1 minute, the desired condition can be achieved. For example, you can configure a threshold of 9.99 to meet the condition >= 10.

If it is necessary to use a Time Type Group as a threshold, a Time Type Group must first be created for the comparison using additional Time Valuations, such as a combination of two Time Valuations of the type "Create Time Record" and "Aggregate Input Groups and Split."

Check Various Conditions Based on Job Info Fields with One Business Rule

In many cases, Time Valuations need to be executed if certain fields in Job Info has certain values. Often, there is a requirement for many different conditions.

This can be achieved using the valuation type "Decision by Business Rule." However, you can quickly reach the maximum allowed number of business rules in Time Valuation. Therefore, a solution with one business rule and various other Time Valuations, whose number is not limited in a Time Recording Profile, would be helpful.

The basic idea is to use a Time Valuation of the type "Calculate by Business Rule" and formulate the different conditions in the business rule. If a condition is met, a fixed value is returned, e.g., 1 hour if condition 1 is met, 2 hours if condition 2 is met...

With various Time Valuations of the type "Compare Threshold with Comparison Group to Route Input," you can then check which value was returned by the previous Time Valuation and route the necessary Time Type Group.

The idea is that the value returned by the business rule is not a value used in the Time Valuation calculations. It is just an indicator that a specific condition is met.

The entire configuration for this would be worth its own blog post.

Configure a Time Recording Profile

Once I feel confident that there are no obstacles and I know how the configuration should look in a Time Recording Profile within Time Tracking, I can start creating and testing the configuration in SuccessFactors Time Tracking.

Before proceeding, I should be able to answer the following questions with a definitive "yes":

  • Have I considered all the necessary steps?
  • Do I know the corresponding valuation type for each step?
  • Does each valuation type support the required functionality, or can I ensure this functionality through other means (e.g., combining multiple time valuations)?
  • Do these steps lead to the desired result?
  • Have I verified the results for the most important test cases (e.g., in a prototype)?

It might be easier to test the isolated requirement in a separate Time Recording Profile first. However, integrating the configuration into existing Time Recording Profiles can still pose a challenge, potentially warranting its own blog post.

I might be able to use already calculated Time Type Groups or reuse existing Time Valuations (for example, in most Time Recording Profiles, breaks from recorded and scheduled times are likely already deducted, and available in a Time Type Group).

Be cautious when using and modifying existing Time Valuations that are also used in other Time Recording Profiles, as this could cause side effects.

A simplified configuration for our example, without considering every detail, might look like this.

Time Recording Profile Visualization for our example

Test the Configuration

You're almost there. Congratulations if you've made it this far, whether you're reading this blog post or dealing with an actual requirement.

However, a very important part is still missing, which could be the subject of numerous extensive blog posts or even books. Testing is crucial to ensure that correct results are calculated in all scenarios and that the configuration does not have side effects on existing configurations in the affected Time Recording Profiles.

Often, I use the prototype for this purpose. Once I have created the prototype and verified that the results are correct, I can replicate the individual test cases in Time Tracking and test them with the adjusted Time Recording Profile. If the results match those in the prototype, everything is good. Then, you can check off the requirement and move on to the next challenge in Time Valuation.

I often use the prototype for this purpose. Once I've created the prototype and verified that the results are correct for all different scenarios, I can replicate the individual test cases in Time Tracking and test them with the adjusted Time Recording Profile. If the results match those from the prototype, everything is good. Then, you can check off the requirement and move on to the next challenge in Time Valuation.

It surely makes sense to document prototypes, configurations, or parts of configurations to access them quickly for similar requirements in the future.

 

Try It Out and Let Me Know!

 Time valuation in SAP SuccessFactors Time Tracking is incredibly flexible, but this flexibility can make configuration a bit challenging.

However, I've found that this method often leads to solutions for requirements that initially seemed impossible.

I encourage you to try it out with a specific requirement to see its effectiveness. It's definitely a learning journey, but one that I hope will be worthwhile. I hope that this blog post has provided you with helpful insights and ideas that you can benefit from.

I wish you all the best in tackling your challenges and would love to hear your feedback!

entry.title: Re: Maintenance Order Cost Capitalize To Asset
entry.content:
Hi,

Refer this documentation for the linkages of Maintenance Order types to Settlement Profiles in the standard system: Configuring Settlement Profiles for Maintenance Orders 

By default, looks to be that only WBS and CTR are setup as optional valid settlement receivers in the settlement profiles.

Note that there is a SSCUI named "Create Settlement Profile" where you can edit the default Settlement Profiles (or create and link new profiles)

Refer screenshot below where I have edited the YEAM04 settlement profile (that is linked to the YA02 Proactive Maintenance Order Type) to make the settlement to a Fixed Asset an optional receiver.

Theoretically that should allow you to settle the maintenance order costs to a Fixed Asset, but admittedly I have not done a full end to end test on my end. If you make the config changes in your system and test the capitalisation process, could you please let me know how it goes?

Regards,

Tim

entry.title: Re: Extracting SAP S/4HANA Data (Tables & CDS Views) to E...
entry.content:
The use of RFC modules from the Operational Data Provisioning (ODP) Data Replication API outside of the SAP environment was never intended or supported, as has been clearly documented from the outset. While some partner solutions may have utilized this option within their connectors, it is advisable for customers and implementation partners to verify compatibility and support directly with third-party providers such as Theobald.

Concurrently, if the Data Service Provisioning (DSP) does not fully meet the project requirements, an alternative worth exploring is leveraging SAP BW/4HANA with Open Hub technology. This approach can serve as an effective data distribution.

entry.title: Re: PM Fleet objects - Equipment additional fields for ve...
entry.content:
If you need some additional information on top of what Chris has mentioned.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud does not have a specific equipment category for Fleet, with specific fleet views and functionality (such as the consumption of fuel etc).

Instead we have the standard 'M-Machines' equipment category, that can be adapted as Chris mentioned in order to make an equipment 'fleet specific'.

I have some commentary in a previous topic for this as well: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/fleet-management-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-for-asset-management-public-edition/qaq-p/12797430/comment-id/4170141/emcs_t/S2h8ZW1haWx8a3Vkb3N8TTJTUDZOVElRTEE1WlB8MTI3OTc0MzF8S1VET1N8aEs#M4170141

Regards, 

Tim

entry.title: Re: Datasphere: Using Inherited Standard Variables in Der...
entry.content: Hi Dimitar, not possible. You cannot injest code for security reasons. That is why you can only pass the value. Means Model B will pass to Model A and Model A passes to Model-View. Alternative would be to remove the Model-View parameter (persist the view in case you have performance issues) and then work with derived variables in model B/A. Cheers, Martin

entry.title: Rise With the Phoenix: Your SAPUI5 Coding Journey Using the Demo Kit
entry.content:
The long, hot summer vacation days are coming to an end. September is just around the corner, and it will kick off the busiest period of the year for business.

You are sitting relaxed at your spacious desk, in your favorite chair, looking at your monitor, and getting ready to do what you love: Start coding.  Today, you have a new idea that you want to turn into reality, and you want to do this fast: Code with SAPUI5. Maybe you have an SAP Fiori project coming up in the pipeline, or maybe you want to enter the world of SAP enterprise application development.

So, where should you start learning about SAPUI5 coding? The answer is simple, although initially, your task might seem overwhelming because a quick search on the topic returns hundreds of results.

One of the top search results would most likely be https://ui5.sap.com/, which is indeed the number one, comprehensive resource for improving your SAPUI5 coding skills.

The SAPUI5 SDK, or the Demo Kit, is the one-stop shop for modern developers who want to build state-of-the-art enterprise-grade SAP applications.

Think of the Demo Kit as the comprehensive code playground and learning hub for everything related to SAPUI5. It is built and maintained by hundreds of professionals who have dedicated their careers to building one of the most extensive, secure, and robust web application frameworks.

So, to save valuable time, go to the Demo Kit now and start your coding journey:

1. You will find extensive documentation covering the essentials, developing and extending apps, developing controls, and a What’s New section for all the latest and greatest features and functional capabilities in the most recent version of SAPUI5.

2. The Get Started: Setup, Tutorials, and Demo Apps section includes the foundational, legendary Walkthrough Tutorial, which, according to many in the SAPUI5 world, is the best resource for starting your SAPUI5 journey. The tutorial is available for JavaScript and TypeScript.

3. The API Reference section contains extensive information about all classes, interfaces, namespaces, and functions available within the SAPUI5 framework.

4. Browse, run, and download the Control Samples.

5. In the Demo Apps section, run tests, оpen and download apps, and explore UI5 Concepts in real-life scenarios.

6. The Resources section features dozens of curated development tools, troubleshooting tools, and customization toolboxes, including:

  • Icon Explorer: The right icon conveys more than words. Browse SAP’s extensive collection of icons to find exactly what fits your app’s context and message. 
  • Accessibility Guide: Create apps that are inclusive by design. The Accessibility Guide offers best practices and hands-on examples, whether you're a developer, UX designer, or business user. 
  • Card Explorer: Learn how to use integration cards – widget-like components ideal for dashboards and overview pages. 

Ready? OK, sit tight in your chair, plug in the headset with your favorite concentration music, open the Demo Kit, start your coding journey with SAPUI5, and… rise like the phoenix.

One more thing: Please tell us what’s on your mind. In the top right corner of the Demo Kit, you will find a “Feedback” icon. You can share your thoughts with us and help improve the Demo Kit.

The Demo Kit is also available for OpenUI5.

entry.title: Why SAP BTP Is the Architect’s New Canvas
entry.content:
Introduction

In the evolving world of enterprise IT, solution architects need a development platform that balances agility with structural integrity and SAP BTP delivers just that. It’s not merely a technology stack but it's a canvas where business intent meets technical artistry.

1. BTP Through the Architect’s Lens

SAP BTP combines application development, data & analytics, integration, and AI/automation into one cohesive platform. For example, you can build a microservice in CAP that pushes real-time sales data to a dashboard in SAC using Integration Suite without touching the core S/4HANA code. This helps avoid messy customizations and keeps your architecture clean.

2. Why It Matters for the Business

Using BTP isn’t just about technology but it’s about delivering results faster. Your stakeholders get real-time insights, automated processes, and new capabilities without waiting months for custom S/4HANA changes. BTP helps you stay agile while keeping systems secure and compliant.

3. The Core Pillars You Should Master

As an architect, you should be comfortable with four main areas:

  • Development & Automation: Decide when to use CAP, RAP, or low-code tools like SAP Build Apps depending on business needs and governance.
  • Data & Analytics: Use SAP Analytics Cloud and Datasphere to converge enterprise-wide insights with ease.
  • Integration: Integration Suite delivers APIs, workflows, Event Mesh just plug the right adapter and connect systems seamlessly.
  • Intelligence & Automation: AI services and automation close the loop from predictive insights to autonomous decision-handling

4. Why Architects Should Focus Here

  • Clean Core Strategy: Push extensions into BTP, not into S/4HANA (SAP’s clean-core philosophy).
  • Future-Proof Integrations: Use API-led patterns and composable services to stay nimble.
  • One Platform, Many Scenarios: Your SAC, CAP apps, workflows, and APIs can all live on BTP. This streamlines operations and ensures governance.
  • Pattern Reusability: Build integrations and dashboards once, and reuse them across multiple scenarios.

5. A Real-World Glimpse

Consider a manufacturing enterprise needing real-time sales dashboards. Architecting on BTP means:

Real-Time Integration: Use Integration Suite to funnel S/4HANA data through Event Mesh.

Clean Extensions: Enrich sales logic using CAP-based microservices.

Visualization: Deliver dashboards via SAP Analytics Cloud.

Governance: All components live under a unified BTP administration umbrella.

No messy SAP wrappers, no brittle custom code, just elegant, maintainable architecture.

 

Conclusion

For today’s architect, SAP BTP is less of a toolset and more of a design philosophy, a way to tie business strategy, integration, data, and intelligence into one disciplined, scalable platform. It’s a way to work smarter as an architect. Master it once, and you’re not just configuring systems, but you are shaping the future of your company’s SAP landscape.

#SAPBTP
#SAPSolutionArchitect
#SAPIntegration
#SAPAnalyticsCloud
#CleanCore

entry.title: Re: Maintenance Order Cost Capitalize To Asset
entry.content: Yes, it’s possible, but not directly. only maintenance costs that qualify as capitalizable (like asset improvements) can be routed through investment measures and settled to an Asset Under Construction before becoming a fixed asset. Routine maintenance remains an expense.

entry.title: Re: From ECC to S/4HANA - Available ressources and trainings
entry.content:
Hi @Jonathan_Denis,

SAP changed some names in S/4HANA. PM is now part of Asset Management | SAP Help Portal.

On Learn SAP skills | SAP Learning you find some learning related to asset management:

  • Discovering SAP Enterprise Asset Management
  • Applying SAP S/4HANA Asset Management
  • Configuring SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, Asset Management
  • Get Certified: SAP Certified Associate - SAP S/4HANA Asset Manage (Learning Hub Subscription required)

If you are using Customer Service (CS) then you should be aware that CS is part of the Compatibility Scope. Usage rights expire by the end of 2030. The successor is S/4HANA Service:

  • 2962632 - S4TWL - Customer Service - SAP for Me

General information about S/4HANA:

  • Key Functional Topics in a System Conversion to SAP S/4HANA
  • Mapping your journey to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition : A practical guide for senior IT leadership
  • SAP ERP to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Delta Scope
  • SAP ERP to SAP S/4HANA Delta Scope - SAP Community
  • The TOP Simplification List Items - SAP Community
  • Simplification Item Catalog - SAP for Me
  • 2269324 - Compatibility Scope Matrix for SAP S/4HANA - SAP for Me
  • SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library
  • How to analyze S/4HANA tables with proxy objects - SAP Community

entry.title: SAP public cloud restrictions
entry.content:
We are facing an issue with role management for our accounting profiles. Specifically, we aim to restrict access based on profit centers by excluding a particular set of profit centers, rather than including them. This method is critical because new profit centers are frequently added, and excluding specific ones is more efficient.
The current challenge lies in the restriction field, which only allows specifying values to be included. Our attempt to enter exclusions using the format !(=value) results in values being truncated and recorded incorrectly.
We seek guidance or a solution that would allow us to configure these restrictions in a more flexible manner, enabling exclusions and thereby streamlining access management for dynamically changing profit center configurations.
